body:
**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

so what's interesting to note here is that while the issue probably exists in 0.9 as well, we have a different system of resetting the ".info" there where we do it *after* the connect attempt.  We've moved that up to suit the HAAlchemy use case in 1.0.    but this is an 0.9 issue regardless so when we test we should find a test that looks at it from the perspective of the connection events themselves and not necessarily .info.

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

- Fixed critical issue whereby the pool "checkout" event handler
may be called against a stale connection without the "connect"
event handler having been called, in the case where the pool
attempted to reconnect after being invalidated and failed; the stale
connection would remain present and would be used on a subsequent
attempt.  This issue has a greater impact in the 1.0 series subsequent
to 1.0.2, as it also delivers a blanked-out ``.info`` dictionary to
the event handler; prior to 1.0.2 the ``.info`` dictionary is still
the previous one.
fixes #3497


→ 4096ad0f0980

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

- Fixed critical issue whereby the pool "checkout" event handler
may be called against a stale connection without the "connect"
event handler having been called, in the case where the pool
attempted to reconnect after being invalidated and failed; the stale
connection would remain present and would be used on a subsequent
attempt.  This issue has a greater impact in the 1.0 series subsequent
to 1.0.2, as it also delivers a blanked-out ``.info`` dictionary to
the event handler; prior to 1.0.2 the ``.info`` dictionary is still
the previous one.
fixes #3497

(cherry picked from commit 4096ad0f0980f6940be57aaee85791df8f975cd7)


→ 0aee8eb0015b

**Changes by Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)):**

* changed **status** to closed

**Kövi András ([@akovi](https://github.com/akovi)) wrote:**

I'm seeing this issue while testing Openstack Mistral DB error handling


```
mysql-connector-python==2.1.7
oslo.db==4.33.0
SQLAlchemy==1.2.1

```

Error trace at: http://paste.openstack.org/show/664669/

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

This specific issue has long been fixed though, that could be something else.  Can you send reproduction steps please

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

And launchpad issue so we can track others getting this

**Kövi András ([@akovi](https://github.com/akovi)) wrote:**

It seems like the fault was on my side. I created an extension for the mysqlconnector dialect that considers errno 2003 a disconnect error.  I missed some code path and errno 2055 escaped the disconnect detection, thus, the connection was not invalidated and the oslo_db callbacks were called with invalid state info and the connection was not invalidated. 

The errors were very confusing as the results depended on how MySQL was killed (TERM, KILL, etc.)

Thanks.

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

why using mysqlconnector?  pymysql is the current standard, we know and understand it very well.  mysqlconnector is controlled by Oracle, has lots of odd quirks and they can't even put it on pypi.

**Kövi András ([@akovi](https://github.com/akovi)) wrote:**

You are right that mysqlconnector is quite discomforting. I needed failover capability and couldn't find a way to configure oslo.db to use multiple servers at the same time.

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

we use galera with haproxy for that.

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

there is also proxysql but the openstack world hasn't gotten into that yet.    at some point I need to find time to evaluate it.

**Kövi András ([@akovi](https://github.com/akovi)) wrote:**

Our DBs are on SSL which does not seem to be well supported with haproxy. This is the main reason we opted for the connector. Thanks for the info, it's very useful to know.

issue.title: MySQL 1047 wsrep, .info dictionary not handled in reset invalidation?
issue.body:
**Migrated issue, originally created by Kövi András ([@akovi](https://github.com/akovi))**

It seems like WSREP errors can cause #3497 to reappear.

Example error: InternalError: (1047, u'WSREP has not yet prepared node for application use')

The error was produced in a HA testing environment where the Galera cluster was being being bombarded with errors. The connecting Openstack Mistral service correctly identified the disconnect errors 2013, but seems to have missed the 1047 which caused erroneous connections stay in the pool.

----------------------------------------
Attachments: [sqlalchemy-issue.txt](../wiki/imported_issue_attachments/4225/sqlalchemy-issue.txt)
